Graduate Club

At the annual spring meeting
of the Graduate Club. the
nominating committee reported
that Tom Kelly had been elected
president and Fred Blattner,
vice-president.
The other eleven nominees on
the ballot for the executive
board were elected almost by default, since they were the only
persons consenting to be nominated.

whether the piano purchased for
the clubroom is really necessary
will have an opportunity to express their opinions soon. Twenning

There are no weekends at
Hopkins. No weekends. Friday
comes, then Monday, and there
was no weekend in between. Last
weekend was Parents' Weekend.
The weekend before that was
Big Weekend. Nothing happened
on either one. Not a thing.
The college weekend is an interesting sociological phenomenon. It has grown as college attendance has grown, and it is a
social function unique to our era
and to our culture. At Hopkins,
however, it just doesn't seem to
exist.

and even Queens College get big

every weekend. But not at Hopkins. Nary a group. The best Ye

The Psychology students would

Pre-Meds would be all agog when

made the scene, and for the Historians, Paul Revere and the
Raiders.
The Political Science men
would not fail to hear Plato and
the Republics and for renaissance scholars, Dante and the
Infernos. For the Engineers, it
would of course have to be the

Writing Seminars people would

Poetry students would revel in

Hopkins Art majors would enjoy a weekend program topped

The Rolling Stones, and Chemistry majors would pay a fortune to hear Richy and the Orbitals. ROTC's would eat up Sgt.

the Papas.
By supporting such groups, the
academic world would provide
for itself some island of entertainment in the dreary sea of
work, and Hopkins could have
Big Weekends.

MUSIC
D. Brubeck Quartette
Takes Five Too Many
By PETER ONUF
Hippies and pseudo-Hippies
think a lot of different things
about Brubeck. Hoppies, however, who made the Big Weekend Scene at Shriver were unanimous, if not in enthusiasm,
at least in trying to be enthusiastic. Tweedy old men tapped
their feet and smiled tentatively
at tweedy old ladies; Hopkins
men and girls knew that this
was the real thing. During the
course of the evening, the audience ranged from warm to hot
In responsiveness and personal
comfort, respectively. The Quartette blew cool and cold. If
anyone, Desmond was particularly disappointing—he played
prettily on a couple of ballads,
but generally wasn't interested—
the way he folds his hands over
his axe is cool, however, if nothing else. He only got half worked-up over his own "Take Five,"
and fared only passably on another one of his standard solos
in "Three to Get Ready." His
best moments featured Gene
Wright's steady and always rewarding basswork. Wright, in
fact, even seemed to be enjoying
himself. Morello, however, is
constitutionally unable to smile;
he outcooled even Desmond, who
despite his apathy showed an
occasional sparkle of humanity.
The drummer knew he was good
and, like a true concert favorite,
knew how to get laughs and
noise from the audience. Brubeck himself is hard to figure.
Hippies generally write him off.
He is certainly no Monk, nor is
- he a Bill Evans, but he does have
professional polish and an intelligent approach. If anyone cared,
he did and most of the musically exciting moments of the
evening were during his solos—
some of this excitement was
noise, some polyrhythmic virtuosity, and some, again, simple
Intelligence. There seemed to be
little rapport, however, between
Desmond and Brubeck, and the
Quartette to be at its best depends on this. Brubeck was at
home with his rhythm, though,
and if the swing passages could
be redeemed from Desmond's
tepid interpretations, Brubeck
was able to do it.
Among the numbers performed
was a bit of church jazz, "40
Days," which, if anything, was
a vehicle for some of the better
solos of the evening. The Quartette concluded the regular program with an interesting version
of "Some Day My Prince Will
Come" •

THE COLLEGE PRESIDENT:
HIS CAUSE AND CURE
Oh,sure,you've been busy,what with going to classes,doing
your homework, catching night crawlers, getting married,
picketing—but can't you pause for just a moment and give
thoughtto that dear,dedicated,lonely man in the big white
house on the hill? I refer, of course, to Prexy.
(It is interesting to note that college presidents are always called "Prexy." Similarly, trustees are always called
wfrixie." Associate professors are always called "Axy-Pixy."
Bursars are called "Foxy-Woxy." Students are called
"Algae.")
But I digress. We were speaking of Prexy, a personage
at once august and pathetic. Why pathetic? Well, sir, consider how Prexy spends his days. He is busy, busy, busy.
He talks to deans, he talks to professors, he talks to trustees, he talks to alumni. In fact, he talks to everybody except the one group who could lift his heart and rally his
spirits. I mean, of course, the appealingest, endearingest,
winsomest group in the entire college—delightful you,the
students.
It is Prexy's sad fate to be forever a stranger to your
laughing, golden selves. He can only gaze wistfully out the
window of his big white house on the hill and watch you at
your games and sports and yearn with all his tormented
heart to bask in your warmth. But how? it would hardly
be fitting for Prexy to appear one day at the Union, clad in
an old rowing blazer, and cry gaily, "Heigh-ho, chaps!
Who's for sculling?"
No,friends,Prexy can't get to you. It is up to you to get
to him. Call on him at home.Just drop in unannounced. He
will naturally be a little shy at first,so you must put him at
his ease. Shout,"Howdy-doody,sir! I have come to bring a
little sunshine into your drear and blighted life!" Then
yank his necktie out of his vest and scamper goatlike
around him until he is laughing merrily along with you.
Then hand him a package and say, 'A little gift for you,
sir."
"For me?" he will say,lowering his lids. "You shouldn't
have."

Op, Pop, and Photos From Below
Featured at Museum Reflections About the Draft Test
Too few Hopkins students reta!ze the pleasures that are just
around the corner.
During orientation, freshmen
are led by the hand to the Baltimore Museum of Art. During the
next four years, all too few of
them ever return.
At present, there are three extraordinary exhibits less than a
five-minute walk from Levering.
They range from Renaissance
Jewels through Japanese photographs to pop and op art.
"Pop and Op," an exhibition of
65 graphic works circulating
throughout the country by the
American Federation of Art, includes such contemporary
"greats" as Andy Warhol, Roy
Lichtenstein, John Wesley and
Ellsworth Kelly.
The exhibit is rather more fun
than stimulating or exciting. It is
all as would be expected: the op
dizzies, the pop is good old camp
(thank god Batman is excluded).
Even more exciting is the exhibition of works by three Japanese
photographers, Hiroshi
Hamaya, Koyo
Okada
and
Tokutaro Tanaka. The exhibit
demonstrates well what artistic
heights photography can achieve.
In Japanese artistic tradition,
the photographers concentrate on
particular themes through a sequence of photographs in which
they translate their perceptions
of nature and man into a feeling
and sensitive whole.
Okada, who has spent 50 years

photographing Mt. Fuji, captures
well the many and changing faces
of the mountain in various angles and weather conditions. The
subject is the same, but the photographs differ greatly in theme
and feeling.
Tanaka's photographs of the
white egret, a beautiful and
graceful bird, are filled with
echoes of Japanese brush painting. He uses twigs, plants and
angular structures to show the
symmetry of the bird on a perch
and in flight.
Hamaya captures the drudgery
and hardships of peasant life on
the backcoast of Japan, especially in times of bad weather. It is
a life of constant struggle with
the natural elements of life.
The latest exhibit to arrive at
the museum is the Melvin Gutman Collection of Renaissance
jewels in the recently completed
Renaissance Room of the Decorative Arts Gallery.
The exhibit includes over 200
jewels and jeweled objects de
vertue from all over Europe and
Russia which were made between
the late 1400's and 1700. Most are
of gold, a few of silver, amber,
pearl and ivory.
The greatest tribute to the artistic taste of the museum exhibitors is the room itself, a mahagony panelled 17th century
room transported from England
including authentic Renaissance
furniture, statuary, and stained
glass windows.

We Are Looking For A ...

By CHARLES VERMONT
On the eve of what may be for
some students the most important exam of their academic career, it may be well for those
taking the test not to examine
what they are being subjected to.
A student should always prepare
for an important exam, if not
through actual study, then by
psychological preparation, that is,
by being well-rested or by becoming tense to the point where intelligence is induced. One key
hint on successful test taking is
to avoid asking unsettling questions concerning the meaning of
one's activity during the fortyeight hour period preceding the
test.
Warning: those taking the
Selective Service Examination
should at all costs refrain from
asking penetrating questions because it is likely that one will
not have to penetrate too far in
order to be upset. Many students
are already aware of their own
hypocrisy concerning the war.
Others recognize that the haphazardness and the biases of Selective Service have placed them in
a quandary.
Many of the students at Hopkins, who in one breath denounce
anti-war demonstrators, are turning around tomorrow and in another breath will be taking a test
to avoid fighting in a war which
they advocate. The Selective
Service Exam throws into relief
the hypocrisy of these students.
In fact, this may be the only
good attribute of the test.
"Why Me?"
A question which is commonly
asked by draft-age men is "Why
me?" The draft is certainly haphazard. Only a small percentage
of draft-age men are ever inducted. For instance, in early
1965 Brig. Gen. Lynn D. Smith,
head of the Army's enlisted personnel directorate, stated in Military Review that only 4.6% of
the 10 million between 17 and 26
years of age actually went into
the Army in 1963. With a growing population, universality of
the draft is a bit of a farce.

Nevertheless, the pretense
universality is kept up.

That the draft is hapharzard is
obvious. It is obvious, too, that
it is biased. In the first place it is
biased because those who never
have a chance to go to college
are drafted first. The poor and
members of minority groups,
Negroes, Puerto Ricans, and
Mexican-Americans, make up a
disproportionate percentage of
the armed forces. Thus there is
an element of class privilege involved in 2-S. But the biases do
not stop; they go on to the college level.
Science-Biased
Deferments are granted in
those areas that are critical to
national defense, which in times
of manpower shortages essentially means the sciences. Tomorrow's examination will reflect
this bias, but this is nothing new.
The functions of the Selective
Service go far beyond those of
procuring bodies for the armed
forces. Its director, General Hershey, has already publicly characterized Selective Service as an
ex-officio agency for national
economic planning. Before the
House Armed Services Committee, Hershey stated: "For the
past twenty years the selective
service system has been what we
call a channeler . .. The deferment is the carrot that we have
used to get individuals into occupations and professions that are
said by those in charge of the
government to be the necessary
ones." Economic planning is not
a priori bad. The question is
planning for whom and by whom.
Presently, the emphasis in Amer-

when the draft system was under
attack by Congressional critics.
Johnson Magic
During peacetime (March and
April 1964) a group of Congressmen led by Congressman Curtis
of Missouri and Senators led by
former Sen. Keating of New
York called for a comprehensive
review of the draft. They had the
idea that the manpower practices of the armed forces could
be made less expensive and more
efficient
economically. Some
even felt that conscription could
be abolished during peacetime.
President Johnson headed off this
group by calling for a study of
Selective Service by the Defense
Department. The report has not
come out and is almost a year
overdue. Undoubtedly, Johnson's
move was an exellent piece of
executive hocus-pocus. Now that
the country is at war, attempts
at Selective Service reform may
be branded unpatriotic, just as
criticism of the war is sometimes branded unpatriotic. More
often criticism of the war is just
disregarded by policy makers
who make their policies stick
through public relations. Tomorrow's test is not a public relations item; it is the real thing. Selective Services and the Vietnam
war have made their official arrival on campus.

Netmen Win ToEnd Season,
Enish 2ndIn Mason-Dixon
By JOSH TREEN
The 1966 varsity tennis team
ended its season Tuesday, with a
6-3 drubbing over Franklin and
Marshall. The win gave the Jays
a 6-6 record and a second place
finish in the Mason-Dixon Northern College division for the second year in a row.
The deciding match was the
5-4 loss to Loyola on May 4. After
/
2upsetting the Greyhounds 51
3 Y.! at Homewood, the Jays ventured uptown and absorbed their
second Mason-Dixon loss, the
first coming against RandolphMacon. The loss ended the netmen's chances for a conference
crown as defending champions
Loyola finished the season with
a 7-1 mark. Hopkins, with conference victories over Western
Maryland 8-1 and Catholic University 5-4, compiled a 4-2 record
in conference play.

By JIM SLOAN
The frosh baseball team, sporting greatly improved hitting,
came up with its best effort of
the year against the nine of Glen
Burnie High School last Thursday.
Although they dropped the
game by a count of 4-7, the Baby
Jays outhit their opponents and
led for a good portion of the
contest. Twice leaving the bases
loaded, the nine stranded an astonishing total of nineteen men
during the seven inning game.
Fielding Fathers
The frosh collected four runs
While holding Glen Burnie scoreless until the fourth inning. The
hosts then came up with one run
in the fourth, three in the fifth,
and three in the sixth. Most of
these scores came on Jay fielding
errors.
Hal Thorne performed notably
as the pitcher for the frosh and
gave up only six hits. Because
he was successful in keeping the
ball low, Glen Burnie managed
to pick up only one extra base
hit—a triple. Thorne has shown
improvement
on
the
great
mound. The inferior fielding efforts of his teammates, not his
Ditching, were the main cause of
the demise.
Hitting Improved
Freshman. mentor, Dave Blizzard, was impressed by the
team's effort at the plate, and he
Commented that the hitting "has
greatly improved." The Baby
Jays outhit their opponents by
8-6 while picking up three extra
base hits. Second baseman, Jim
Zuger, highlited the hitting as he
Connected with the first pitch of
the game and walloped a long
triple. Later he came up with a
Solid two-bagger to left field.
Dan Contesti reached first base
four times on a single and three
Walks. Tony Stone also got on
base three times on a walk, an
error, and a long triple. Singles
Were sported by Tom McDonough, Dave Brainerd, Hal Thorne
and Dave Finnley.
Brainerd, who is usually the
froth pitcher, filled in for Rich
Grayson at first. He did a fine
Job considering his lack of practice at the position.

Interview By JEFF WEIDIG,
Wilson Fewster is not disillusioned, disgusted, nor embittered by the undergraduate attitude toward sports or by the
seemingly disinterested administration. Surprisingly enough, he
has more hope and enthusiasm
than ever before.
N-L: What does the future
hold for intercollegiate'sports at
Hopkins?
"Four years ago I would never
have said this, but now I'm firmly convinced that sports at Hopkins, and football in particular,
is going to take a surge upward.
I'm sure that the administration
now seeks the all-around student-athlete rather than the boy
whose interest lies solely in the
realm of scholarship.
"A few years ago, they placed
more emphasis on obtaining the
scholar, and emen though the
school's scholastic image rose,
you could walk across campus,
pass perhaps fifty or so people
and never even get so much as
a glance of recognition. To a
freshman, the atmosphere was
depressing, apathetic and rather
insular. Now the administration
Is cognizant of the need for a
healthier atmosphere and of the
value of the gifted athletic student. Most often, the athlete is a
leader on campus and is more
enthusiastic about extra-curricular activities and group organisations of campus—and it can't
be denied that enthusiasm is
needed in that area of campus
activity.
"Identification with some sort
of athletic image is certainly a
good part of the answer to the
need for a more energetic atmosphere. A good football team
and basketball team gives a certain spirit and pride to the unand
dergraduate — freshmen
sophomores especially. As it is
now, a freshman comes to Hopkins filled with enthusiasm that
lasts all of about three weeks.
It endures until we tie Ursinus
and ends when we get clobbered
by Hampton-Sydney or Dickinson. Then our young freshman
prefers to sit in the snack bar on
Saturday and watch the game of
the week, and I can't say that I
blame him. Sometimes I'd rather
not watch the game either.
"Presently, Johns Hopkins is
showing signs of life. With the
new library and the new athletic
center, we have the facilities to
compete with the Ivy League.

Profile

Benson Honored
As Trainer
"Jimmy Benson Day" was declared last Saturday on Homewood Field in appreciation of
the trainer's forty years of service to Hopkins' athletics.
Marshall Turner, Director of
Physical Education and Athletics
remarke d, "Jimmy doesn't
have the background of modern
trainers, but he certainly does a
fine job. He has sought help
from the doctors and other people available, and he has kept
up with many of the modern
methods."
Whenever questioned people
always reply that what they
like best about Benson is his intense loyalty to the University
and the cor.;thes. Players often
gripe to him when they come in
for treatment or a "whirlpool,"
but Jimmy doesn't stand for any
comments against the coaches.
Those who are amiable receive
the same courtesy, but those who
are arrogant receive little more
than attention to their sprains
or bruises.
"How good a trainer is Benson?" one might ask. "Well, I
dislocated my thigh on the field
one time," said senior footballer
Jeff Weidig, "and he put it right
back, on the spot, for me."
Jimmy Benson was given a
wristwatch and a hearty pat on
the back, but it was made clear
to everyone present that this
was not a farewell but just a
thanks.

There are no weekends at
Hopkins. No weekends. Friday
comes, then Monday, and there
was no weekend in between. Last
weekend was Parents' Weekend.
The weekend before that was
Big Weekend. Nothing happened
on either one. Not a thing.
The college weekend is an interesting sociological phenomenon. It has grown as college attendance has grown, and it is a
social function unique to our era
and to our culture. At Hopkins,
however, it just doesn't seem to
exist.

and even Queens College get big

Raiders.
The Political Science men

Writing Seminars people would

MUSIC
D. Brubeck Quartette
Takes Five Too Many
By PETER ONUF
Hippies and pseudo-Hippies
think a lot of different things
about Brubeck. Hoppies, however, who made the Big Weekend Scene at Shriver were unanimous, if not in enthusiasm,
at least in trying to be enthusiastic. Tweedy old men tapped
their feet and smiled tentatively
at tweedy old ladies; Hopkins
men and girls knew that this
was the real thing. During the
course of the evening, the audience ranged from warm to hot
In responsiveness and personal
comfort, respectively. The Quartette blew cool and cold. If
anyone, Desmond was particularly disappointing—he played
prettily on a couple of ballads,
but generally wasn't interested—
the way he folds his hands over
his axe is cool, however, if nothing else. He only got half worked-up over his own "Take Five,"
and fared only passably on another one of his standard solos
in "Three to Get Ready." His
best moments featured Gene
Wright's steady and always rewarding basswork. Wright, in
fact, even seemed to be enjoying
himself. Morello, however, is
constitutionally unable to smile;
he outcooled even Desmond, who
despite his apathy showed an
occasional sparkle of humanity.
The drummer knew he was good
and, like a true concert favorite,
knew how to get laughs and
noise from the audience. Brubeck himself is hard to figure.
Hippies generally write him off.
He is certainly no Monk, nor is
- he a Bill Evans, but he does have
professional polish and an intelligent approach. If anyone cared,
he did and most of the musically exciting moments of the
evening were during his solos—
some of this excitement was
noise, some polyrhythmic virtuosity, and some, again, simple
Intelligence. There seemed to be
little rapport, however, between
Desmond and Brubeck, and the
Quartette to be at its best depends on this. Brubeck was at
home with his rhythm, though,
and if the swing passages could
be redeemed from Desmond's
tepid interpretations, Brubeck
was able to do it.
Among the numbers performed
was a bit of church jazz, "40
Days," which, if anything, was
a vehicle for some of the better
solos of the evening. The Quartette concluded the regular program with an interesting version
of "Some Day My Prince Will
Come" •

THE COLLEGE PRESIDENT:
HIS CAUSE AND CURE
Oh,sure,you've been busy,what with going to classes,doing
your homework, catching night crawlers, getting married,
picketing—but can't you pause for just a moment and give
thoughtto that dear,dedicated,lonely man in the big white
house on the hill? I refer, of course, to Prexy.
(It is interesting to note that college presidents are always called "Prexy." Similarly, trustees are always called
wfrixie." Associate professors are always called "Axy-Pixy."
Bursars are called "Foxy-Woxy." Students are called
"Algae.")
But I digress. We were speaking of Prexy, a personage
at once august and pathetic. Why pathetic? Well, sir, consider how Prexy spends his days. He is busy, busy, busy.
He talks to deans, he talks to professors, he talks to trustees, he talks to alumni. In fact, he talks to everybody except the one group who could lift his heart and rally his
spirits. I mean, of course, the appealingest, endearingest,
winsomest group in the entire college—delightful you,the
students.
It is Prexy's sad fate to be forever a stranger to your
laughing, golden selves. He can only gaze wistfully out the
window of his big white house on the hill and watch you at
your games and sports and yearn with all his tormented
heart to bask in your warmth. But how? it would hardly
be fitting for Prexy to appear one day at the Union, clad in
an old rowing blazer, and cry gaily, "Heigh-ho, chaps!
Who's for sculling?"
No,friends,Prexy can't get to you. It is up to you to get
to him. Call on him at home.Just drop in unannounced. He
will naturally be a little shy at first,so you must put him at
his ease. Shout,"Howdy-doody,sir! I have come to bring a
little sunshine into your drear and blighted life!" Then
yank his necktie out of his vest and scamper goatlike
around him until he is laughing merrily along with you.
Then hand him a package and say, 'A little gift for you,
sir."
"For me?" he will say,lowering his lids. "You shouldn't
have."

Op, Pop, and Photos From Below
Featured at Museum Reflections About the Draft Test
Too few Hopkins students reta!ze the pleasures that are just
around the corner.
During orientation, freshmen
are led by the hand to the Baltimore Museum of Art. During the
next four years, all too few of
them ever return.
At present, there are three extraordinary exhibits less than a
five-minute walk from Levering.
They range from Renaissance
Jewels through Japanese photographs to pop and op art.
"Pop and Op," an exhibition of
65 graphic works circulating
throughout the country by the
American Federation of Art, includes such contemporary
"greats" as Andy Warhol, Roy
Lichtenstein, John Wesley and
Ellsworth Kelly.
The exhibit is rather more fun
than stimulating or exciting. It is
all as would be expected: the op
dizzies, the pop is good old camp
(thank god Batman is excluded).
Even more exciting is the exhibition of works by three Japanese
photographers, Hiroshi
Hamaya, Koyo
Okada
and
Tokutaro Tanaka. The exhibit
demonstrates well what artistic
heights photography can achieve.
In Japanese artistic tradition,
the photographers concentrate on
particular themes through a sequence of photographs in which
they translate their perceptions
of nature and man into a feeling
and sensitive whole.
Okada, who has spent 50 years

photographing Mt. Fuji, captures
well the many and changing faces
of the mountain in various angles and weather conditions. The
subject is the same, but the photographs differ greatly in theme
and feeling.
Tanaka's photographs of the
white egret, a beautiful and
graceful bird, are filled with
echoes of Japanese brush painting. He uses twigs, plants and
angular structures to show the
symmetry of the bird on a perch
and in flight.
Hamaya captures the drudgery
and hardships of peasant life on
the backcoast of Japan, especially in times of bad weather. It is
a life of constant struggle with
the natural elements of life.
The latest exhibit to arrive at
the museum is the Melvin Gutman Collection of Renaissance
jewels in the recently completed
Renaissance Room of the Decorative Arts Gallery.
The exhibit includes over 200
jewels and jeweled objects de
vertue from all over Europe and
Russia which were made between
the late 1400's and 1700. Most are
of gold, a few of silver, amber,
pearl and ivory.
The greatest tribute to the artistic taste of the museum exhibitors is the room itself, a mahagony panelled 17th century
room transported from England
including authentic Renaissance
furniture, statuary, and stained
glass windows.

We Are Looking For A ...

By CHARLES VERMONT
On the eve of what may be for
some students the most important exam of their academic career, it may be well for those
taking the test not to examine
what they are being subjected to.
A student should always prepare
for an important exam, if not
through actual study, then by
psychological preparation, that is,
by being well-rested or by becoming tense to the point where intelligence is induced. One key
hint on successful test taking is
to avoid asking unsettling questions concerning the meaning of
one's activity during the fortyeight hour period preceding the
test.
Warning: those taking the
Selective Service Examination
should at all costs refrain from
asking penetrating questions because it is likely that one will
not have to penetrate too far in
order to be upset. Many students
are already aware of their own
hypocrisy concerning the war.
Others recognize that the haphazardness and the biases of Selective Service have placed them in
a quandary.
Many of the students at Hopkins, who in one breath denounce
anti-war demonstrators, are turning around tomorrow and in another breath will be taking a test
to avoid fighting in a war which
they advocate. The Selective
Service Exam throws into relief
the hypocrisy of these students.
In fact, this may be the only
good attribute of the test.
"Why Me?"
A question which is commonly
asked by draft-age men is "Why
me?" The draft is certainly haphazard. Only a small percentage
of draft-age men are ever inducted. For instance, in early
1965 Brig. Gen. Lynn D. Smith,
head of the Army's enlisted personnel directorate, stated in Military Review that only 4.6% of
the 10 million between 17 and 26
years of age actually went into
the Army in 1963. With a growing population, universality of
the draft is a bit of a farce.

Nevertheless, the pretense
universality is kept up.

That the draft is hapharzard is
obvious. It is obvious, too, that
it is biased. In the first place it is
biased because those who never
have a chance to go to college
are drafted first. The poor and
members of minority groups,
Negroes, Puerto Ricans, and
Mexican-Americans, make up a
disproportionate percentage of
the armed forces. Thus there is
an element of class privilege involved in 2-S. But the biases do
not stop; they go on to the college level.
Science-Biased
Deferments are granted in
those areas that are critical to
national defense, which in times
of manpower shortages essentially means the sciences. Tomorrow's examination will reflect
this bias, but this is nothing new.
The functions of the Selective
Service go far beyond those of
procuring bodies for the armed
forces. Its director, General Hershey, has already publicly characterized Selective Service as an
ex-officio agency for national
economic planning. Before the
House Armed Services Committee, Hershey stated: "For the
past twenty years the selective
service system has been what we
call a channeler . .. The deferment is the carrot that we have
used to get individuals into occupations and professions that are
said by those in charge of the
government to be the necessary
ones." Economic planning is not
a priori bad. The question is
planning for whom and by whom.
Presently, the emphasis in Amer-

when the draft system was under

Johnson Magic
During peacetime (March and
April 1964) a group of Congressmen led by Congressman Curtis
of Missouri and Senators led by
former Sen. Keating of New
York called for a comprehensive
review of the draft. They had the
idea that the manpower practices of the armed forces could
be made less expensive and more
efficient
economically. Some
even felt that conscription could
be abolished during peacetime.
President Johnson headed off this
group by calling for a study of
Selective Service by the Defense
Department. The report has not
come out and is almost a year
overdue. Undoubtedly, Johnson's
move was an exellent piece of
executive hocus-pocus. Now that
the country is at war, attempts
at Selective Service reform may
be branded unpatriotic, just as
criticism of the war is sometimes branded unpatriotic. More
often criticism of the war is just
disregarded by policy makers
who make their policies stick
through public relations. Tomorrow's test is not a public relations item; it is the real thing. Selective Services and the Vietnam
war have made their official arrival on campus.

By JOSH TREEN
The 1966 varsity tennis team
ended its season Tuesday, with a
6-3 drubbing over Franklin and
Marshall. The win gave the Jays
a 6-6 record and a second place
finish in the Mason-Dixon Northern College division for the second year in a row.

5-4 loss to Loyola on May 4. After

crown as defending champions
Loyola finished the season with
a 7-1 mark. Hopkins, with conference victories over Western
Maryland 8-1 and Catholic University 5-4, compiled a 4-2 record
in conference play.

decidedly different from the first

6-0 respectively. Although Hopkins swept the first two doubles
matches, Loyola's two freshmen,
Smith and Weller combined to
trip Butler and Ellenbogen in
third doubles 9-7, 6-4, to give
Loyola the match.

By JIM SLOAN
The frosh baseball team, sporting greatly improved hitting,
came up with its best effort of
the year against the nine of Glen
Burnie High School last Thursday.
Although they dropped the
game by a count of 4-7, the Baby
Jays outhit their opponents and
led for a good portion of the
contest. Twice leaving the bases
loaded, the nine stranded an astonishing total of nineteen men
during the seven inning game.
Fielding Fathers
The frosh collected four runs
While holding Glen Burnie scoreless until the fourth inning. The
hosts then came up with one run
in the fourth, three in the fifth,
and three in the sixth. Most of
these scores came on Jay fielding
errors.
Hal Thorne performed notably
as the pitcher for the frosh and
gave up only six hits. Because
he was successful in keeping the
ball low, Glen Burnie managed
to pick up only one extra base
hit—a triple. Thorne has shown
improvement
on
the
great
mound. The inferior fielding efforts of his teammates, not his
Ditching, were the main cause of
the demise.
Hitting Improved
Freshman. mentor, Dave Blizzard, was impressed by the
team's effort at the plate, and he
Commented that the hitting "has
greatly improved." The Baby
Jays outhit their opponents by
8-6 while picking up three extra
base hits. Second baseman, Jim
Zuger, highlited the hitting as he
Connected with the first pitch of
the game and walloped a long
triple. Later he came up with a
Solid two-bagger to left field.
Dan Contesti reached first base
four times on a single and three
Walks. Tony Stone also got on
base three times on a walk, an
error, and a long triple. Singles
Were sported by Tom McDonough, Dave Brainerd, Hal Thorne
and Dave Finnley.
Brainerd, who is usually the
froth pitcher, filled in for Rich
Grayson at first. He did a fine
Job considering his lack of practice at the position.

Sports Seen Surging Here Jays Seek To Halt
By Retiring Coach Fewster Middie Win Skein
Interview By JEFF WEIDIG,
Wilson Fewster is not disillusioned, disgusted, nor embittered by the undergraduate attitude toward sports or by the
seemingly disinterested administration. Surprisingly enough, he
has more hope and enthusiasm
than ever before.
N-L: What does the future
hold for intercollegiate'sports at
Hopkins?
"Four years ago I would never
have said this, but now I'm firmly convinced that sports at Hopkins, and football in particular,
is going to take a surge upward.
I'm sure that the administration
now seeks the all-around student-athlete rather than the boy
whose interest lies solely in the
realm of scholarship.
"A few years ago, they placed
more emphasis on obtaining the
scholar, and emen though the
school's scholastic image rose,
you could walk across campus,
pass perhaps fifty or so people
and never even get so much as
a glance of recognition. To a
freshman, the atmosphere was
depressing, apathetic and rather
insular. Now the administration
Is cognizant of the need for a
healthier atmosphere and of the
value of the gifted athletic student. Most often, the athlete is a
leader on campus and is more
enthusiastic about extra-curricular activities and group organisations of campus—and it can't
be denied that enthusiasm is
needed in that area of campus
activity.
"Identification with some sort
of athletic image is certainly a
good part of the answer to the
need for a more energetic atmosphere. A good football team
and basketball team gives a certain spirit and pride to the unand
dergraduate — freshmen
sophomores especially. As it is
now, a freshman comes to Hopkins filled with enthusiasm that
lasts all of about three weeks.
It endures until we tie Ursinus
and ends when we get clobbered
by Hampton-Sydney or Dickinson. Then our young freshman
prefers to sit in the snack bar on
Saturday and watch the game of
the week, and I can't say that I
blame him. Sometimes I'd rather
not watch the game either.
"Presently, Johns Hopkins is
showing signs of life. With the
new library and the new athletic
center, we have the facilities to
compete with the Ivy League.

The varsity lacrosse team travels to Annapolis tomorrow, in
trying to do what no college
team has done since June, 1963.
Navy, who lost to Army, 11-9,
three years ago, is undefeated
collegiately since, and has lost
only once, to the powerful Mount
Washington Wolfpack.
Coach Bill Bilderback's squad
is led by the great Jim Lewis,
two-time first team All-America
and twice winner of the Turnbull
award, given annually to the best
attackman to play on Maryland
soil. The 5-9, 160 lb. Uniondale,
L.I. product does everything —
shoots, feeds, dodges and rides
—phenomenally, and is rated by
many — including Jay assistant
coach Henry Ciccarone—as the
best to ever play the game.
Others on Navy's all-senior
first attack crew include Loyola
High grad Owen McFadden;
Frank Markowski, who will probably play the crease when he is
in the game; and 6-5, 210 lb.
Sparrows Point native Bob
Bandy.

lbs.; and Dick Salmon, rated by
Hopkins coach Bob Scott as the

consistent midfield scorer.

Profile

Benson Honored
As Trainer
"Jimmy Benson Day" was declared last Saturday on Homewood Field in appreciation of
the trainer's forty years of service to Hopkins' athletics.
Marshall Turner, Director of
Physical Education and Athletics
remarke d, "Jimmy doesn't
have the background of modern
trainers, but he certainly does a
fine job. He has sought help
from the doctors and other people available, and he has kept
up with many of the modern
methods."
Whenever questioned people
always reply that what they
like best about Benson is his intense loyalty to the University
and the cor.;thes. Players often
gripe to him when they come in
for treatment or a "whirlpool,"
but Jimmy doesn't stand for any
comments against the coaches.
Those who are amiable receive
the same courtesy, but those who
are arrogant receive little more
than attention to their sprains
or bruises.
"How good a trainer is Benson?" one might ask. "Well, I
dislocated my thigh on the field
one time," said senior footballer
Jeff Weidig, "and he put it right
back, on the spot, for me."
Jimmy Benson was given a
wristwatch and a hearty pat on
the back, but it was made clear
to everyone present that this
was not a farewell but just a
thanks.
